title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions for disparities in polling place availability. The Voting Rights Act is amended to recognize tribal identification documents as valid for voting purposes. The Attorney General has the authority to take legal actions, including against States, in the name of the United States. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act recognizes tribal identification as valid for voting. The Attorney General can take legal actions, including against States, to address disparities in voting opportunities for Indian tribe members. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act allows tribal identification for voting. Legal actions can be taken to address voting disparities for Indian tribe members, including increasing polling place availability through injunctive relief granted by district courts. The judges designated to hear voting disparity cases must expedite the process. There is a presumption that such disparities deny voting rights based on race or color. An aggrieved person can take legal action to address these disparities. An aggrieved person can bring legal action if their voting rights are denied based on race or color, despite the guarantees set forth in the law. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include protections for Indian reservations, requiring approval for activities like eliminating polling places or moving them further away. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions like eliminating or moving polling places further away, especially if it hinders voter access. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions like eliminating in-person voting, designating reservations as permanent absentee voting locations, and diminishing early voting opportunities. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions like reducing early voting opportunities or changing voting dates on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include protections for Indian reservations, requiring approval for changes to voting procedures on reservations. Federal election oversight on Indian reservations is addressed in Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, requiring approval for changes to voting procedures on reservations. Section 8 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if complaints of voter suppression are received from tribal organizations. SEC. 5 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 regarding the termination of election observers. SEC. 6 provides definitions. SEC. 6 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 provides definitions, including the terms 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' as defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. It also defines 'member of an Indian tribe' to include individuals who are members of Indian tribes or Native Corporations. SEC. 7 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to update bilingual election requirements and the definition of Indian reservation. SEC. 8 focuses on election observer transparency. SEC. 8 requires the Attorney General to publicly release reports of Federal election observers within 6 months. SEC. 9 mandates annual consultation with tribal organizations on voting issues for Indian tribes.
